Sun of Faith - English: The yaksa spirit Shakya Vardhana dwelt in Kapilavastu and the Shakyas honored him as the guardian of their clan. There was a custom that, when a Shakya boy or girl was born, one prayed first to Shakya Vardhana, so the King prepared to do so. He brought the young Bodhisattva on a palenquin made from four kinds of jewels. Accompanied by a large retinue, including the King and his ministers, [the Bodhisattva] entered the grounds of Kapilavastu.
Manual - English: In a mansion, there is the king along with a retinue. The Buddha takes the form of a boy on the king's lap.  There are brahmins before the king. The king is in a carriage on the road, surrounded by a large retinue. A palanquin with the Buddha and his nanny on it is held up by a large crowd. In a temple, a yakṣa wearing an armor prostrates the Buddha.

Sun of Faith - English: As soon as the Bodhisattva entered the grounds of Kapilavastu, Even the fierce, rough, and rash Shakyas who carried on noisily were chastened and pacified. The became speechless, like sages practicing an ascetic vow. The ill-mannered Shakyas, seated like sages, knew this to be the power of the Bodhisattva. Thus, he was named Shakyamuni, Sage of the Shakyas.

When the Bodhisattva approached Shakya Vardhanana's sanctuary, the statue of the spirit himself emerged from his temple, touched the Bodhisattva's feet and prayed. The entire crowd saw this and said, “This divine spirit bows at his feet. He is a god among gods!” Hence God of Gods was added to the litany of his names.
Inscription - English: The yaksha spirit prostrates to the Shakya youth

Sun of Faith - English: Then the Bodhisattva was entrusted to eight nurses, and cared for all of the finest things. Even his father would hold him in his lap, and would think about him often.

At that time the King called for the brahmin diviners and all soothsayers, and questioned them. Most knew that the Bodhisattva's body had the thirty-two signs of a great being, and they prophesied, "If he remains at home he will become a universal monarch. But if leaves home to become homeless, he will become the Thus Gone One, a Worthy One, a Totally Perfect Buddha."
Seven days after the birth of the Bodhisattva, his mother died. She was immediately rereborn into the sublime family of gods in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.

In those days one could not get enough of looking upon the Bodhisattva. His voice was sweet and carried far. Day and night his eyes never closed as he gazed all around. And he could recognize profound sayings and writings.
